body: I'm fine with that, as long as it's consistent across the entire class.

> I'm fine with that, as long as it's consistent across the entire class.

Yes, the whole state machine would not be thread safe.

I am fine to declare the state machine as thread unsafe. 

I think we can start on using big lock in IMRU driver. For the reasons of
- Driver is a central place for all the evaluators, ensure thread safe at driver level makes sense.
- Even the driver methods are public, we know we are the client of IMRU driver. 

The draw back of big lock is performance. But let's make it safe first and then if there is performance issue, do optimization.

@jwang98052  Left some comments.

I agree with @anupam128. This change is way too big. It literally crashed the browser tab when I tried to do a code review.

There is also limited documentation on the design. Hence, I will comment on that here in the hopes that a set of smaller commits can replace this one.

The code seems to overspecialize on the case of combining the local runtime with another one. The configuration builder goes so far as to expose specific options of the local runtime again in methods. This seems unnecessary to me, as we already have ways to configure each runtime. I was hoping for a multi runtime layer that would allow for the generic combination of any runtime. That should not only be more general, but also much simpler from a code perspective.

In terms of breaking this change down into a set of smaller commits that each have a specific focus, how about the following:
1. Introduce multi-runtime API with support for 0 actual runtimes. That commit should introduce the new interfaces for the user of the multi runtime as well as the new interfaces for runtimes that would like to take part in a multi-runtime setup. Tests in this commit can validate invariants of the multi-runtime APIs.
2. Add support for the local runtime to take part in a multi-runtime setup. In this commit, we can also add a new launcher for `HelloREEF` that uses the multiruntime in this configuration.
3. Add support for the yarn runtime to take part in a multi-runtime setup. We can expand the test and `HelloREEF` coverage in this commit.
4. Add support for the HDI runtime as above.

I expect step 1 in this plan to be the most review-heavy, but it is also a cheap way to evade the need for a lengthy design plan discussion. I find it easier to discuss code than design docs, but this PR as presented is just too much.

@shulmanb Do you think that sequence of events is feasible? Or is there another that makes more sense?

@afchung You've had a chance to look at the code, is the above reasonable? I'm making this up in the void, after all :)

jwang98052 some of major concerns/questions have been answered by @tcNickolas . It would be good to have comment on a) Definition of final states; and b) some of unusual/edge case transitions for completeness sake for users who would not look at design doc. Otherwise LGTM.

@markusweimer I think even if we will go down this rout the java part will remain unchanged, as the bootstrap code still need exist for Yarn based multi runtime. We can make it as the first commit. Also currently we don't have any interfaces on the c# client side,

Current implementation does not specialized on yarn/local, the reason builder supports only these two is that nothing else is supported on the c# layer, and I don't see it happening in the near future. I layed out this exact plan in the JIRA ~3 weeks ago and did not receive any comments.

> I think even if we will go down this rout the java part will remain unchanged, as the bootstrap code still need exist for Yarn based multi runtime. We can make it as the first commit.

That sounds good to me. As long as the JIRA and commit message make it clear how it all fits together, separating along the language boundary makes sense.

> Current implementation does not specialized on yarn/local, the reason builder supports only these two is that nothing else is supported on the c# layer, 

That is fair. However, leaking local runtime configuration parameters to the multi runtime builder is dangerous, as we now have to pay attention to the multi runtime when changing the local runtime. This tight coupling will become an issue.

Hence, my suggestion is to make the multi-runtime agnostic to the specific runtime, and expose APIs that a runtime needs to implement to take part in the multi-runtime setup. That way, the dependency is explicit and obvious.

> I layed out this exact plan in the JIRA ~3 weeks ago and did not receive any comments. 

My bad, code is easier to discuss than short design notes.

I agree with @markusweimer's proposal. This code review is too big, and every time a new commit is pushed I need to re-read everything again to make sure that things still make sense. Laying out a plan does not mean that the PR should include every step described in the plan all at once.

> Hence, my suggestion is to make the multi-runtime agnostic to the specific runtime, and expose APIs that a runtime needs to implement to take part in the multi-runtime setup. That way, the dependency is explicit and obvious.

This was what I meant when I commented on how the `MultiRuntimeConfigurationBuilder` should consist of a `Builder` of `RuntimeConfigurationBuilder`s. The way it's designed right now jumbles everything together and 1) makes the code hard to understand 2) puts runtime-specific checks in the `MultiRuntimeConfigurationBuilder`.

That said, this PR is already in progress and quite a bit of time has already been invested, should we just open JIRA items for improvement and move on with the PR? @markusweimer @shulmanb what do you think?

> That said, this PR is already in progress and quite a bit of time has already been invested, should we just open JIRA items for improvement and move on with the PR?

Maybe. I'd prefer to use the fixes made to be part of a series of smaller commits.

Thank you for picking this up! :-)

Considering scenarios for logger usage, I think both "modifying log level for only one logger instance" and "modifying log level for all instances from certain point" are valid scenarios for various debug purposes. Previously our code supported only the second one, with the proposed change it would support only the first one. I think we should support both.

We can have two log level fields: one static and one per instance. They can be set independently, and when a message arrives to be logged, it is logged if either of level fields dictates it to be logged. Or per instance field could have priority, if it was set explicitly instead of staying on default value.

What do you think?
I will have a look.
@shulmanb done with a first pass.
@markusweimer @tcNickolas I have addressed your review comments.

@afchung  LGTM. I am wondering if Cache() should be added in DataLoadingContext in IMRU as part of this or later... Plus it would be good to check IMRU and make sure it did not break anything.

Once you are done with all reviews, ping me to check IMRU on cluster and I will. You can do it also :) if you want.

We definitely want to test any changes in those classes in both local and Yarn. I have HadoopFileInputPartitionTest, you might want to update  for Yarn testing. 

When test it with IMRU, we need to set  copytolocal both true and false to test it.

Yes, I agree. Having both per instance and global level makes sense.
For logging, I think the second scenario makes more sense: if a user sets a per instance log level, that should always be used, and otherwise, fall back to always using the global log level. Since there is no `Level.Unset` value, does a `bool` per instance flag make sense as a way to assert that the per instance level has been set (this would avoid the confusion of a user that sets the per instance field to the default value ...).

Finally, I can leave the existing code to make use of the global log level; I only changed it for now to avoid compilation issues.

Let me know if that makes sense.
LGTM. I'll test and merge this.

@shulmanb done with a first pass.
A hacky workaround would be to use an array for this. When it is empty, it means that the item is not bound. If its size is bigger than 1, we bail. It is a hack, but could work.

If we have a "default" value for level, user setting per-instance field to it would be equivalent to `Unset`, so that's fine for me (marginally better than separate boolean flag). We just have to be careful to check that global log level doesn't get set to "default"
